values.description:
This is used by pull request #95.

Note that the components which hold SDF objects are not comparable at the moment, but that should be ok since we're not planning on using the `EntityByComponents` function (pull request #101) with them now, and probably ever.

Also added the `TagWrapper` class, inspired by `SimpleWrapper`.
values.title: Add equality operators to several component types

summary.raw:
This is used by pull request #95.

Note that the components which hold SDF objects are not comparable at the moment, but that should be ok since we're not planning on using the `EntityByComponents` function (pull request #101) with them now, and probably ever.

Also added the `TagWrapper` class, inspired by `SimpleWrapper`.

This is used by pull request #95.

Note that the components which hold SDF objects are not comparable at the moment, but that should be ok since we're not planning on using the EntityByComponents function (pull request #101) with them now, and probably ever.

values.description:
Add an `ignition::gazebo::Model` class which plugins can use to access model-specific API.

We're still currently debating how best to store `EntityComponentManager`, so for now, it needs to be passed in every API call.

Needs:

* ~~pull request #101~~
* ~~pull request #102~~

Needed by:

* pull request #95
values.title: Beginning of Model API class

summary.raw:
Add an `ignition::gazebo::Model` class which plugins can use to access model-specific API.

We're still currently debating how best to store `EntityComponentManager`, so for now, it needs to be passed in every API call.

Needs:

* ~~pull request #101~~
* ~~pull request #102~~

Needed by:

* pull request #95
summary.html:
Add an ignition::gazebo::Model class which plugins can use to access model-specific API.

We're still currently debating how best to store EntityComponentManager, so for now, it needs to be passed in every API call.

Needs:

  • pull request #101
  • pull request #102

Needed by:

  • pull request #95

values.title: Pass components by const ref in EntityByComponents and related functions

values.description:
Split executables into:

* `ign-gazebo-gui`: Runs GUI, equivalent to `gzclient`
* `ign-gazebo-server`: Runs server, equivalent to `gzserver`
* `ign-gazebo`: Main entry point, may spin up GUI and Server according to arguments.

---

## TODO

Done!

---

@JChoclin, @iche033 : if you start integrating sensors, you can build on top of this branch so that the GUI's rendering doesn't get in the way of the sensors' rendering.
values.title: Split processes

values.description:
Start if ign-fuel-tools integration.

1. Adds dependency on ign-fuel tools. Another PR will make use of this dependency.

2. Adds link to ign-math in `src/CMakeLists.txt`. I ran into a situation where ign-math4 was installed in `/usr`, which was pulled in by a dependency. This caused ign-gazebo to find ign-math4 first, and not use ign-math6.

3. Added missing include in SimulationRunner.hh
values.title: Fuel tools part1

summary.raw:
Start if ign-fuel-tools integration.

1. Adds dependency on ign-fuel tools. Another PR will make use of this dependency.

2. Adds link to ign-math in `src/CMakeLists.txt`. I ran into a situation where ign-math4 was installed in `/usr`, which was pulled in by a dependency. This caused ign-gazebo to find ign-math4 first, and not use ign-math6.

3. Added missing include in SimulationRunner.hh
summary.html:
Start if ign-fuel-tools integration.

  1. Adds dependency on ign-fuel tools. Another PR will make use of this dependency.

  2. Adds link to ign-math in src/CMakeLists.txt. I ran into a situation where ign-math4 was installed in /usr, which was pulled in by a dependency. This caused ign-gazebo to find ign-math4 first, and not use ign-math6.

  3. Added missing include in SimulationRunner.hh

values.description:
## Try it out

From the root of the `ign-gazebo` directory, run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/mesh.sdf`

It needs to be run from the root so that the mesh's relative path is correct.

![ducks.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/389605541-ducks.gif)

## Rendering

Since rendering right now is only used in the GUI, and outside of the ECS, all it needed was the mesh information on the scene message.

It needs [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/181/gz11-dont-override-mesh-material/diff) for collada materials to show up.

And [this PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/126/prevent-crash-for-invalid-mesh/diff) prevents crashes for invalid meshes.

## Physics

Physics is the only consumer of mesh information from the ECS right now, so I'm just loading the mesh in the physics system as a placeholder, building on top of @scpeters's changes.

### Issues

* Mesh seems to be correctly created, but the ducks don't collide with the ground plane. I'll debug more tomorrow with the help of @azeey.

## TODOs

* Load mesh outside of physics so that it can be propagated to other systems via a component
* Use `ign-fuel-tools` to load meshes
values.title: [WIP] Mesh support

## Try it out

From the root of the `ign-gazebo` directory, run:

`ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/mesh.sdf`

It needs to be run from the root so that the mesh's relative path is correct.

![ducks.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/389605541-ducks.gif)

## Rendering

Since rendering right now is only used in the GUI, and outside of the ECS, all it needed was the mesh information on the scene message.

Physics is the only consumer of mesh information from the ECS right now, so I'm just loading the mesh in the physics system as a placeholder, building on top of @scpeters's changes.

summary.html:
Try it out

From the root of the ign-gazebo directory, run:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/mesh.sdf

It needs to be run from the root so that the mesh's relative path is correct.

Rendering

Since rendering right now is only used in the GUI, and outside of the ECS, all it needed was the mesh information on the scene message.

It needs this PR for collada materials to show up.

And this PR prevents crashes for invalid meshes.

Physics

Physics is the only consumer of mesh information from the ECS right now, so I'm just loading the mesh in the physics system as a placeholder, building on top of @scpeters's changes.

Issues

  • Mesh seems to be correctly created, but the ducks don't collide with the ground plane. I'll debug more tomorrow with the help of @azeey.

TODOs

  • Load mesh outside of physics so that it can be propagated to other systems via a component
  • Use ign-fuel-tools to load meshes

values.description:
The pull request implements a level system based on the idea that a simulation runner is responsible for loading and unloading all levels in the world.

## Dependencies:

* ~~ign-physics branch [remove_model_features](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/branch/remove_entity_features)~~
      * ~~Which in turn depends on ign-physics [pull request #46](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/46/)~~
* ~~ign-gui [pull request #182](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/182)~~


## TODOs:

* ~~Send only new entities to ign-gui instead of the whole scene when new entities are added~~
* ~~Add tests for the level manager.~~

## To test
Create a benchmark world using `benchmark.world.erb`

```
$ erb n_x=8 n_y=8 test/worlds/benchmark.sdf.erb > test/worlds/benchmark.sdf
```
Run ign-gazebo with `--levels` flag
```
$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/benchmark.sdf --levels
```
Before starting the simulation, publish command velocities to the red and green vehicles.

```
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_red/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"

```
Then start the simulation.

## Levels on
![ign_gazebo_levels_on2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1414413745-ign_gazebo_levels_on2.gif)
## Levels off
![ign_gazebo_levels_off2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2684170126-ign_gazebo_levels_off2.gif)
values.title: [A-1] Levels

summary.raw:
The pull request implements a level system based on the idea that a simulation runner is responsible for loading and unloading all levels in the world.

## Dependencies:

* ~~ign-physics branch [remove_model_features](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/branch/remove_entity_features)~~

## TODOs:

* ~~Send only new entities to ign-gui instead of the whole scene when new entities are added~~
* ~~Add tests for the level manager.~~

## To test
Create a benchmark world using `benchmark.world.erb`

```
$ erb n_x=8 n_y=8 test/worlds/benchmark.sdf.erb > test/worlds/benchmark.sdf
```
Run ign-gazebo with `--levels` flag
```
$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/benchmark.sdf --levels
```
Before starting the simulation, publish command velocities to the red and green vehicles.

```
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_red/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"

```
Then start the simulation.

## Levels on
![ign_gazebo_levels_on2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1414413745-ign_gazebo_levels_on2.gif)
## Levels off
![ign_gazebo_levels_off2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2684170126-ign_gazebo_levels_off2.gif)
summary.html:
The pull request implements a level system based on the idea that a simulation runner is responsible for loading and unloading all levels in the world.

Dependencies:

  • ign-physics branch remove_model_features
    • Which in turn depends on ign-physics pull request #46
  • ign-gui pull request #182

TODOs:

  • Send only new entities to ign-gui instead of the whole scene when new entities are added
  • Add tests for the level manager.

To test

Create a benchmark world using benchmark.world.erb

$ erb n_x=8 n_y=8 test/worlds/benchmark.sdf.erb > test/worlds/benchmark.sdf

Run ign-gazebo with --levels flag

$ ign-gazebo -v 4 -f test/worlds/benchmark.sdf --levels

Before starting the simulation, publish command velocities to the red and green vehicles.

ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_red/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"
ign topic -t "/model/vehicle_blue/cmd_vel" -m ignition.msgs.Twist -p "linear: {x: 2.5}"

Then start the simulation.

Levels on

Levels off

values.description:
This requires:

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/82
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/180
* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/127

Once this is ready, you'll be able to specify world files with:

```
    <include>
      <uri>https://fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/1.0/nate/models/my_Backpack</uri>
    </include> 
```

Try out:

```
ign-gazebo -f examples/worlds/empty.world
```

![fuel-tools.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/4154114752-fuel-tools.png)

values.description:
Make sure you have a joystick connected. If using docker, be sure to run with `--device=/dev/input/js0`.

On one terminal:

~~~
cd examples/standalone/joystick
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
./joystick ../joystick.sdf
~~~

On another terminal:

~~~
cd examples/standalone/joy_to_twist
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
./joy_to_twist ../joy_to_twist.sdf
~~~

On a 3rd terminal:

~~~
cd ign-gazebo
ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/diff_drive.sdf
~~~

Unpause and command away!

---

## TODO (MVP)

* ~~Finish passing SDF args for `joy_to_twist`~~
* ~~Fix style~~

Done!

## TODO (future)

* "launch" standalone programs from `ign-gazebo`?
* Integration tests
values.title: Joystick teleop

values.description:
Inspired by the work started [here](https://bitbucket.org/JChoclin/ign-gazebo/branch/ign_sensors_integration#chg-src/SimulationRunner.cc) by @JChoclin.

Needs [this SDF PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/488/port-pull-request-481-to-gz11/diff).

I'm not convinced of the current architecture yet, as I'm not sure exactly how Ignition Sensors is meant to be used. We may want to split it into multiple systems... one per sensor, one per group of sensors? 

---

## Try it out!

Run the example world:

    ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/camera_sensor.sdf

Echo images to see they're indeed  being published:

    ign topic -e -t /camera

---

## TODO

* Decide on the architecture
* ~~Populate scene from components~~
* Add ign-sensors as a dependency on CI
* Add tests
* ~~Port ign-gui's image viewer to QtQuick so we can see the camera images~~
* Try multiple cameras
* ... anything else?
values.title: [WIP] Camera sensors

Inspired by the work started here by @JChoclin.

Needs this SDF PR.

I'm not convinced of the current architecture yet, as I'm not sure exactly how Ignition Sensors is meant to be used. We may want to split it into multiple systems... one per sensor, one per group of sensors?

Try it out!

Run the example world:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f ../examples/worlds/camera_sensor.sdf

Echo images to see they're indeed being published:

ign topic -e -t /camera

TODO

  • Decide on the architecture
  • Populate scene from components
  • Add ign-sensors as a dependency on CI
  • Add tests
  • Port ign-gui's image viewer to QtQuick so we can see the camera images
  • Try multiple cameras
  • ... anything else?

values.description:
While debugging test failures on pull request #106, I noticed that the inline namespace for the conversion functions wasn't correct, because it didn't have the `config` header.

Fixing that lead to an unexpected problem, the compiler started complaining that the templates had multiple definitions. So based on [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/4445772/6451468) I moved their implementation to a cc file, where they probably should've been all along :slight_smile:
values.title: Fix inline namespace for conversion functions

summary.raw:
While debugging test failures on pull request #106, I noticed that the inline namespace for the conversion functions wasn't correct, because it didn't have the `config` header.

Fixing that lead to an unexpected problem, the compiler started complaining that the templates had multiple definitions. So based on [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/4445772/6451468) I moved their implementation to a cc file, where they probably should've been all along :slight_smile:
summary.html:
While debugging test failures on pull request #106, I noticed that the inline namespace for the conversion functions wasn't correct, because it didn't have the config header.

Fixing that lead to an unexpected problem, the compiler started complaining that the templates had multiple definitions. So based on this I moved their implementation to a cc file, where they probably should've been all along

values.description:
This is needed by pull request #111 in order to send new and erased entities to the ign-gui.
I have refactored some of the code so it might be easier to review this by changesets:

* ce68a4e: Use ISystemConfigure for SceneBroadcaster to initialize the world Id and name.

* 949b04d: Create a topic for publishing a scene with new entities.

    This uses EachNew to create a scene message consisting of only new entities. This changeset also introduces a change in the content of the scene graph in `SceneBroadcaster`.  The data in each node is now the message associated with that entity only. i.e, a model node only has a message only about the model. It will not have any links, joints, etc. To create a the whole scene, one has to traverse the whole graph adding messages as necessary.

* f64d08a: Add topic to notify clients when entities get deleted

    Currently only model entities are supported for deletion

* 3e09413: Refactor free functions in SceneBroadcaster to be static member functions so they can use graph type alias
values.title: Broadcaster publishes new and erased entities

summary.raw:
This is needed by pull request #111 in order to send new and erased entities to the ign-gui.
I have refactored some of the code so it might be easier to review this by changesets:

* ce68a4e: Use ISystemConfigure for SceneBroadcaster to initialize the world Id and name.

* 949b04d: Create a topic for publishing a scene with new entities.

    This uses EachNew to create a scene message consisting of only new entities. This changeset also introduces a change in the content of the scene graph in `SceneBroadcaster`.  The data in each node is now the message associated with that entity only. i.e, a model node only has a message only about the model. It will not have any links, joints, etc. To create a the whole scene, one has to traverse the whole graph adding messages as necessary.

* f64d08a: Add topic to notify clients when entities get deleted

    Currently only model entities are supported for deletion

* 3e09413: Refactor free functions in SceneBroadcaster to be static member functions so they can use graph type alias
summary.html:
This is needed by pull request #111 in order to send new and erased entities to the ign-gui. I have refactored some of the code so it might be easier to review this by changesets:

  • ce68a4e: Use ISystemConfigure for SceneBroadcaster to initialize the world Id and name.

  • 949b04d: Create a topic for publishing a scene with new entities.

    This uses EachNew to create a scene message consisting of only new entities. This changeset also introduces a change in the content of the scene graph in SceneBroadcaster. The data in each node is now the message associated with that entity only. i.e, a model node only has a message only about the model. It will not have any links, joints, etc. To create a the whole scene, one has to traverse the whole graph adding messages as necessary.

  • f64d08a: Add topic to notify clients when entities get deleted

    Currently only model entities are supported for deletion

  • 3e09413: Refactor free functions in SceneBroadcaster to be static member functions so they can use graph type alias

summary.html:
This pull request is split from pull request #111. It is used to move a model in 3d space by setting the linear velocity of its links.

Dependencies:

  • ign-physics pull request #46

values.description:
Builds on top of pull request #114

Also requires ign-sensors [pull request #27](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/27/componentize-plugins/diff) \(update: merged\), and ign-cmake `gz11` branch

ign-gui [pull request #184](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/184/migrate-imagedisplay-to-qml/diff) \(update: merged\) is optional but helps to see the camera sensor data visualized in the gui.

A scene manager class is added to populate the scene based on components received through the Entity Component Manager. The functionality currently duplicates the one in ign-gui Scene3d plugin. We’ll need to come up with a plan to merge the two together.

Here’s the camera sensor data visualized in ign-gui:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3726824267-ign_sensor_data.png)
‌

The brightness in the ign-gui 3D render window \(left\) looks way off :confused: I had thought it was due to the switch to PBR in ogre2 but now I’ll have to revisit this issue and study how ogre2 does gamma correction in order to do the same for the 3D render window.
values.title: Integrate sensors system

Builds on top of pull request #114

Also requires ign-sensors [pull request #27](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/27/componentize-plugins/diff) \(update: merged\), and ign-cmake `gz11` branch

Here’s the camera sensor data visualized in ign-gui:

‌

The brightness in the ign-gui 3D render window \(left\) looks way off :confused: I had thought it was due to the switch to PBR in ogre2 but now I’ll have to revisit this issue and study how ogre2 does gamma correction in order to do the same for the 3D render window.
summary.html:
Builds on top of pull request #114

Also requires ign-sensors pull request #27 (update: merged), and ign-cmake gz11 branch

ign-gui pull request #184 (update: merged) is optional but helps to see the camera sensor data visualized in the gui.

A scene manager class is added to populate the scene based on components received through the Entity Component Manager. The functionality currently duplicates the one in ign-gui Scene3d plugin. We’ll need to come up with a plan to merge the two together.

Here’s the camera sensor data visualized in ign-gui:

‌

The brightness in the ign-gui 3D render window (left) looks way off I had thought it was due to the switch to PBR in ogre2 but now I’ll have to revisit this issue and study how ogre2 does gamma correction in order to do the same for the 3D render window.

values.description: Just something I noticed, I don't think we need both an `EntityId` definition and an `Entity` class which wraps an ID. They have been used interchangeably in the API, so I think we can just remove `Entity`.

values.description:
This PR depends on [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/52/). This allows the physics system to respect the `<mesh><scale>` SDF element that can be set by users.

However, we should wait to merge this, because I’ve noticed that rendering engine does not seem to account for the SDF mesh scale currently. I’m honestly not sure how to adjust a mesh’s scale for the renderer. If anyone knows how to make that happen, please feel free to make the change in this PR, and then we can consider merging it.

The related `ign-physics` PR can be merged at any time without any negative side effects.
values.title: [Do not merge] Pass the <scale> information from sdf to the physics engine

summary.raw:
This PR depends on [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/52/). This allows the physics system to respect the `<mesh><scale>` SDF element that can be set by users.

However, we should wait to merge this, because I’ve noticed that rendering engine does not seem to account for the SDF mesh scale currently. I’m honestly not sure how to adjust a mesh’s scale for the renderer. If anyone knows how to make that happen, please feel free to make the change in this PR, and then we can consider merging it.

The related `ign-physics` PR can be merged at any time without any negative side effects.
summary.html:
This PR depends on this ign-physics PR. This allows the physics system to respect the <mesh><scale> SDF element that can be set by users.

However, we should wait to merge this, because I’ve noticed that rendering engine does not seem to account for the SDF mesh scale currently. I’m honestly not sure how to adjust a mesh’s scale for the renderer. If anyone knows how to make that happen, please feel free to make the change in this PR, and then we can consider merging it.

The related ign-physics PR can be merged at any time without any negative side effects.

values.description:
Built on top of pull request #114 and pull request #117 \(which depends on ign-physics [pull request #46](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/46)\). It’s probably best to review these first.

Added an altimeter system. Given that it is still unclear how we’re going to integrate sensors, I decided to implement the altimeter inside the system without depending on ign-sensors. This also means that the current implementation does not support setting noise or update rate. We can move to ign-sensors later if needed.

I also added the following new components:

* Altimeter
* WorldPose
* WorldLinearVelocity

Let me know if I should put the World\* components in separate files - currently I just put them in Pose.hh and LinearVelocity.hh.

‌

To test, run:

    ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/altimeter_sensor.sdf

In another terminal, echo the `/altimeter` topic

    ign topic -e -t /altimeter

Hit play to start simulation and see altimeter data printed in the terminal
values.title: Add Altimeter system

summary.html:
Built on top of pull request #114 and pull request #117 (which depends on ign-physics pull request #46). It’s probably best to review these first.

Added an altimeter system. Given that it is still unclear how we’re going to integrate sensors, I decided to implement the altimeter inside the system without depending on ign-sensors. This also means that the current implementation does not support setting noise or update rate. We can move to ign-sensors later if needed.

I also added the following new components:

  • Altimeter
  • WorldPose
  • WorldLinearVelocity

Let me know if I should put the World* components in separate files - currently I just put them in Pose.hh and LinearVelocity.hh.

‌

To test, run:

ign-gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/altimeter_sensor.sdf

In another terminal, echo the /altimeter topic

ign topic -e -t /altimeter

Hit play to start simulation and see altimeter data printed in the terminal

values.description:
After having some experience with the new architecture, it felt like it would be more convenient to store the entity hierarchy as a graph in the manager, than to use the `ParentEntity` component.

See [these comments](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/111/wip-levels/activity#comment-87433928) for more context.

---

## Summary

* Changes `EntityComponentManager::entities` from a vector to a graph.
* Adds a few convenience functions to the manager, like `ParentEntity`, `ChildByComponents` and `Entities`.
* Changes `CreateEntity` so the parent needs to be passed.
* Changes `RequestEraseEntity` so it erases all descendants recursively.
* Unlike the component, which could be rewritten, now it's impossible to reparent an entity until we explicitly implement this.

---

## Migration

### Querying for the parent

Before:

`auto parentEntity = ecm.Component<components::ParentEntity>(entity);`

Now:

`auto parentEntity = ecm.ParentEntity(entity)`

### Setting a parent

Before:

~~~
    auto entity = this->CreateEntities(light);

    this->entityCompMgr.CreateComponent(entity,
        components::ParentEntity(parentEntity));
~~~

Now:

~~~
    auto entity = this->entityCompMgr.CreateEntity(parentEntity);
    this->CreateEntities(light, entity);
~~~

---

@azeey , I'm testing integrating this into pull request #111 on branch `entity_graph_levels`.
values.title: [Proposal] Store entity graph in ECM

* Unlike the component, which could be rewritten, now it's impossible to reparent an entity until we explicitly implement this.

Now:

`auto parentEntity = ecm.ParentEntity(entity)`

### Setting a parent

        components::ParentEntity(parentEntity));
~~~

Now:

    this->CreateEntities(light, entity);
~~~

---

@azeey , I'm testing integrating this into pull request #111 on branch `entity_graph_levels`.
summary.html:
After having some experience with the new architecture, it felt like it would be more convenient to store the entity hierarchy as a graph in the manager, than to use the ParentEntity component.

See these comments for more context.

Summary

  • Changes EntityComponentManager::entities from a vector to a graph.
  • Adds a few convenience functions to the manager, like ParentEntity, ChildByComponents and Entities.
  • Changes CreateEntity so the parent needs to be passed.
  • Changes RequestEraseEntity so it erases all descendants recursively.
  • Unlike the component, which could be rewritten, now it's impossible to reparent an entity until we explicitly implement this.

Migration

Querying for the parent

Before:

auto parentEntity = ecm.Component<components::ParentEntity>(entity);

Now:

auto parentEntity = ecm.ParentEntity(entity)

Setting a parent

Before:

    auto entity = this->CreateEntities(light);

    this->entityCompMgr.CreateComponent(entity,
        components::ParentEntity(parentEntity));

Now:

    auto entity = this->entityCompMgr.CreateEntity(parentEntity);
    this->CreateEntities(light, entity);

@azeey , I'm testing integrating this into pull request #111 on branch entity_graph_levels.

values.description:
This PR moves the API used to create entities and components from SDF to a public class that can be used by systems (similar to `Model.hh`).

Important details:

* The `LoadPlugins` event is used to load plugins on demand. It's recommended that systems call this during the `PreUpdate` callback.
* After talking to @azeey, we thought we may give it a try at keeping raw pointers to the managers within the factory object. This should always be safe, since we expect managers to outlive the API (instantiated by systems). If this PR is merged, I'll make another PR doing the same for `gazebo::Model`.
* Pull request #111 moves the `CreateEntities` functions to the new `LevelManager` class so it can keep a convenient graph of entities. I'll make a subsequent PR to move the graph to the ECM as it was proposed on pull request #127, but keeping the `ParentEntity`, and offering a convenient `Factory::SetParent` function which keeps things in sync for the end user.
values.title: Factory API

summary.raw:
This PR moves the API used to create entities and components from SDF to a public class that can be used by systems (similar to `Model.hh`).

Important details:

* The `LoadPlugins` event is used to load plugins on demand. It's recommended that systems call this during the `PreUpdate` callback.
* After talking to @azeey, we thought we may give it a try at keeping raw pointers to the managers within the factory object. This should always be safe, since we expect managers to outlive the API (instantiated by systems). If this PR is merged, I'll make another PR doing the same for `gazebo::Model`.
* Pull request #111 moves the `CreateEntities` functions to the new `LevelManager` class so it can keep a convenient graph of entities. I'll make a subsequent PR to move the graph to the ECM as it was proposed on pull request #127, but keeping the `ParentEntity`, and offering a convenient `Factory::SetParent` function which keeps things in sync for the end user.
summary.html:
This PR moves the API used to create entities and components from SDF to a public class that can be used by systems (similar to Model.hh).

Important details:

  • The LoadPlugins event is used to load plugins on demand. It's recommended that systems call this during the PreUpdate callback.
  • After talking to @azeey, we thought we may give it a try at keeping raw pointers to the managers within the factory object. This should always be safe, since we expect managers to outlive the API (instantiated by systems). If this PR is merged, I'll make another PR doing the same for gazebo::Model.
  • Pull request #111 moves the CreateEntities functions to the new LevelManager class so it can keep a convenient graph of entities. I'll make a subsequent PR to move the graph to the ECM as it was proposed on pull request #127, but keeping the ParentEntity, and offering a convenient Factory::SetParent function which keeps things in sync for the end user.

values.description:
This builds on top of ~~pull request #129~~ **merged**

---

This is an alternative to pull request #127 which has both `components::ParentEntity` and a graph within the ECM storing the parent-child relationship between entities. Since keeping these in sync is prone to errors, we provide convenient functions in `gazebo::Factory` which do the correct thing so the end user doesn't need to worry about it.
values.title: [A-6] Entity graph + factory

values.description:
Trying to break this up into nice, review-able chunks.

The networking peer tracker is the bottom layer for the distributed simulation to detect and track available peers.

This is used by higher-level functionality to determine when it is okay to execute simulation.

Updated to test the use of ign-transport partitions to separate multiple instances of distributed simulation on the same subnet.

values.description:
The scripts are split out so that they could potentially be used by other build pipelines \(such as bitbucket or jenkins\) and have the changes reflected everywhere they are used.

This container is being built specifically in support of distributed simulation, other applications would just be bonus.

values.description:
`include/ignition/gazebo/EntityComponentManager.hh` is becoming large and it's hard to navigate it. This PR moves classes `View` and `ComponentStorageBase` to their own headers, since these are not meant to be used downstream. It also creates a new `detail/EntityComponentManager.hh` just with template implementations, so what's left on the main header is just the declarations of the public API.

---

While not strictly necessary for milestone 6, I'm planning to build on top of this PR.
values.title: [A-6]  Move classes not meant to be used directly to /detail

summary.raw:
`include/ignition/gazebo/EntityComponentManager.hh` is becoming large and it's hard to navigate it. This PR moves classes `View` and `ComponentStorageBase` to their own headers, since these are not meant to be used downstream. It also creates a new `detail/EntityComponentManager.hh` just with template implementations, so what's left on the main header is just the declarations of the public API.

---

While not strictly necessary for milestone 6, I'm planning to build on top of this PR.
summary.html:
include/ignition/gazebo/EntityComponentManager.hh is becoming large and it's hard to navigate it. This PR moves classes View and ComponentStorageBase to their own headers, since these are not meant to be used downstream. It also creates a new detail/EntityComponentManager.hh just with template implementations, so what's left on the main header is just the declarations of the public API.

While not strictly necessary for milestone 6, I'm planning to build on top of this PR.

values.description:
This is a question that came to mind while reviewing pull request #130. The `Factory` class is a wrapper around some functionality in ECM. Everything seems fine if `Factory` is removed, and all the functionality is placed in `ECM`. So, what's the purpose behind the `Factory` class?

Without the Factory class we avoid storing the address to a reference parameter (Factory was storing a pointer to ECM, which was passed in by reference). There are no more duplicate functions, such as `RequestEraseEntity`, and System implementors can go to one spot, `ECM`, for their needs.

Is there a bigger plan for the `Factory` class?
values.title: Remove factory?

summary.raw:
This is a question that came to mind while reviewing pull request #130. The `Factory` class is a wrapper around some functionality in ECM. Everything seems fine if `Factory` is removed, and all the functionality is placed in `ECM`. So, what's the purpose behind the `Factory` class?

Without the Factory class we avoid storing the address to a reference parameter (Factory was storing a pointer to ECM, which was passed in by reference). There are no more duplicate functions, such as `RequestEraseEntity`, and System implementors can go to one spot, `ECM`, for their needs.

Is there a bigger plan for the `Factory` class?
summary.html:
This is a question that came to mind while reviewing pull request #130. The Factory class is a wrapper around some functionality in ECM. Everything seems fine if Factory is removed, and all the functionality is placed in ECM. So, what's the purpose behind the Factory class?

Without the Factory class we avoid storing the address to a reference parameter (Factory was storing a pointer to ECM, which was passed in by reference). There are no more duplicate functions, such as RequestEraseEntity, and System implementors can go to one spot, ECM, for their needs.

Is there a bigger plan for the Factory class?

values.reason: I have a better understanding of the goals now.

values.description:
# Overview

Add the `UserCommands` system, which is meant to be the entry point for all user commands. This is just the beginning of the system, it eventually will:

* Provide a transport interface for **all commands** such as spawning, deleting, moving, etc.
* Provide a transport interface to **undo / redo** previous commands.
* Provide a transport interface to get a **history** of commands.

Right now, all it provides is a single command: spawn.

# Requirements

* Pull request #130 (merged)
* [ign-msgs 86](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/86/a-6-refactor-factory/diff) (merged)
* [sdf 499](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/499/a-6-support-root/diff) (merged)

# Try it out

The instructions in `empty.sdf` should be enough, let me know if you need more instructions.

![spawn.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2909024988-spawn.gif)

# Future work

The current architecture is inspired on Gazebo's [UserCmdManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/physics/UserCmdManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) and [MEUserCmdManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/gui/model/MEUserCmdManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default).

The intention is that undo / redo will work as described on [this design document](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/src/b84d3c4b82f666b2ef6a989032ac61530e1ee32f/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default); for that, we will need a way to store and restore simulation keyframes - this functionality is tied to the current development of simulation logging.
values.title: [A-6] User command: Spawn / factory / create

summary.raw:
# Overview

Add the `UserCommands` system, which is meant to be the entry point for all user commands. This is just the beginning of the system, it eventually will:

* Provide a transport interface for **all commands** such as spawning, deleting, moving, etc.
* Provide a transport interface to **undo / redo** previous commands.
* Provide a transport interface to get a **history** of commands.

Right now, all it provides is a single command: spawn.

# Requirements

* Pull request #130 (merged)
* [ign-msgs 86](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/86/a-6-refactor-factory/diff) (merged)
* [sdf 499](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/499/a-6-support-root/diff) (merged)

# Try it out

The instructions in `empty.sdf` should be enough, let me know if you need more instructions.

![spawn.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2909024988-spawn.gif)

# Future work

The current architecture is inspired on Gazebo's [UserCmdManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/physics/UserCmdManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default) and [MEUserCmdManager](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/gazebo/gui/model/MEUserCmdManager.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default).

The intention is that undo / redo will work as described on [this design document](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_design/src/b84d3c4b82f666b2ef6a989032ac61530e1ee32f/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default); for that, we will need a way to store and restore simulation keyframes - this functionality is tied to the current development of simulation logging.
summary.html:
Overview

Add the UserCommands system, which is meant to be the entry point for all user commands. This is just the beginning of the system, it eventually will:

  • Provide a transport interface for all commands such as spawning, deleting, moving, etc.
  • Provide a transport interface to undo / redo previous commands.
  • Provide a transport interface to get a history of commands.

Right now, all it provides is a single command: spawn.

Requirements

  • Pull request #130 (merged)
  • ign-msgs 86 (merged)
  • sdf 499 (merged)

Try it out

The instructions in empty.sdf should be enough, let me know if you need more instructions.

Future work

The current architecture is inspired on Gazebo's UserCmdManager and MEUserCmdManager.

The intention is that undo / redo will work as described on this design document; for that, we will need a way to store and restore simulation keyframes - this functionality is tied to the current development of simulation logging.

values.description:
Includes imu and magnetometer sensors with their tests.

There is still a difference between the physics gravity and the world gravity. I think that makes the imu test to have a really big tolerance. I think we can fix getting from physics the gravity value or setting the gravity with the value from SDF before merge. Worse case scenario I include the into the test sdf the same value used in physics.  
  
This follows [Ian’s altimeter approach](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/?state=MERGED) and it is strongly based on that PR. I think we should move later this sensors into ign-sensors but we decided that can be discussed after Acropolis release.  
  
Also it is worth considering the [discussion](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1294/inclusion-of-magnetic-field-strength) that included the magnetometer the first time. There is a lot of room for improvements.
values.title: [A-5] Add magnetometer and imu sensors

values.description:
**Requires** [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/170/a-string-to-uint64_t-hash-function/diff) pull request from Ignition Common.

This pull request implements a factory, where all components self-register. Besides our original discussion, I ended up creating a `Component` base class, as is needed for the `Factory` class.

Components can be created based on strings or ids \(uint64\_t\). I changed they way we were assigning the Ids in the `EntityComponentManager` class. Now, we use `ignition::common::hash64`.
values.title: [A-4] Component factory

summary.raw:
**Requires** [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/170/a-string-to-uint64_t-hash-function/diff) pull request from Ignition Common.

This pull request implements a factory, where all components self-register. Besides our original discussion, I ended up creating a `Component` base class, as is needed for the `Factory` class.

Components can be created based on strings or ids \(uint64\_t\). I changed they way we were assigning the Ids in the `EntityComponentManager` class. Now, we use `ignition::common::hash64`.
summary.html:
Requires this pull request from Ignition Common.

This pull request implements a factory, where all components self-register. Besides our original discussion, I ended up creating a Component base class, as is needed for the Factory class.

Components can be created based on strings or ids (uint64_t). I changed they way we were assigning the Ids in the EntityComponentManager class. Now, we use ignition::common::hash64.

values.description:
Just addressing some confusing API. Speak up if you have better ideas for the names.

* Renamed `Factory` to `SdfEntityCreator` to avoid a common confusion that it was a reference to the [factory pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factory_(object-oriented_programming))
* We have parts of the API using the word **remove** and other parts using **erase** - I changed all to remove, but speak up if you'd prefer to change things the other way around.

This pull request just renames files and functions - nothing else has been changed.

---

Summary:

* `Factory` -> `SdfEntityCreator`
* `Erase` -> `Remove`
* `Erased` -> `Removed`
* `Erasure` -> `Removal`
values.title: [debt] Rename Factory and Erase

* We have parts of the API using the word **remove** and other parts using **erase** - I changed all to remove, but speak up if you'd prefer to change things the other way around.

summary.html:
Just addressing some confusing API. Speak up if you have better ideas for the names.

  • Renamed Factory to SdfEntityCreator to avoid a common confusion that it was a reference to the factory pattern
  • We have parts of the API using the word remove and other parts using erase - I changed all to remove, but speak up if you'd prefer to change things the other way around.

This pull request just renames files and functions - nothing else has been changed.

Summary:

  • Factory -> SdfEntityCreator
  • Erase -> Remove
  • Erased -> Removed
  • Erasure -> Removal

This is broken off pull request #143.

Update existing systems so they support entities created at runtime, as opposed to only entities loaded from SDF at startup.
values.title: [A-6] Support entity creation at runtime

values.description: This pull request builds on top of pull request #111. It adds a performance test using a world with a number of static objects and two performers. I opted for a very simple test that just compares the amount of time it takes to run 1000 iterations as fast as possible.
values.title: [A-1] Performance test for the level manager
